revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 1 as dead.) #IABot (v2.0
revision.text:
{{short description|American serial killer on death row}} {{Infobox serial killer | name= Paul Durousseau | image= Paul Durousseau.jpg | caption=Durousseau's mug shot | birthname= Paul Durousseau | alias=The Jacksonville Strangler | birth_date={{Birth date and age|1970|08|11}} | birth_place=[[Beaumont, Texas]], U.S. | height=6 ft 6 in (1.98 m) | victims=7+ | country=[[United States|U.S.]], possibly [[Germany]] | states=[[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Florida]] | beginyear=January 6, 1997 | endyear=January 20, 2003 | apprehended=June 17, 2003 | penalty=[[Capital punishment|Death]] }}
'''Paul Durousseau''' (born August 11, 1970)<ref name="DOC">{{cite web |url=http://www.dc.state.fl.us/ActiveInmates/inmateaction.asp?DataAction=GetInmate&DCNumber=J19087 |title=Inmate Population Information Detail - Paul Durousseau |publisher=[[Florida Department of Corrections]] |accessdate=February 6, 2010 }}</ref> is an [[United States|American]] [[serial killer]] who [[murder]]ed seven young women (including two who were [[pregnant]]) in the southeastern United States between 1997 and 2003. [[Germany|German]] authorities suspect he may have killed several local women when he was stationed there with the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] during the early 1990s. Typically, Durousseau would gain the victim's trust, enter the victim's home, tie their hands, [[rape]], then [[Strangling|strangle]] them to death.<ref name="radford">Ferguson, George, Emily Downing, Kaylor Eutsler, & David Disque. [http://maamodt.asp.radford.edu/Psyc%20405/serial%20killers/Durousseau,%20Paul%20_Fall,%202006_.pdf ''Paul Durousseau: The Jacksonville Serial Killer''.] Radford University Dept of Psychology.</ref> All of his known victims were young, single [[African-American]] women.
== Personal life == Paul Durousseau was born in [[Beaumont, Texas|Beaumont]], [[Texas]]. In 1971, he moved in with his mother's family in [[Los Angeles]] after his father, unwed to his mother, deserted them. Little else is known publicly about Durousseau's childhood. After graduating high school, 19-year-old Durousseau found himself working as a security guard. His first offenses as an adult took place on December 18, 1991 and January 21, 1992 for [[Concealed carry in the United States|carrying a concealed firearm]] in [[California]].<ref name="jacksonville.com">{{cite web | last = Chapin | first = Veronica | title = Cabdriver arrested in 6 serial killings | work = jacksonville.com | publisher = The Florida Times-Union | date = 18 June 2003 | url = http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/061803/met_12819930.shtml | accessdate = }}</ref>
In November 1992, Durousseau enlisted in the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]]<ref name="jacksonville.com"/> and was stationed in [[Germany]], where he met Natoca, who would later become his wife. The two married in 1995 in [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]]. In 1996, they were transferred to [[Fort Benning]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. On March 13, 1997, Durousseau was arrested for [[kidnapping]] and [[Rape|raping]] a young woman. However, in August of that year he was cleared of those charges. Soon after, he was found in possession of stolen goods. He was [[court-martial]]ed in January 1999, found guilty and [[Dishonorable discharge#Dishonorable|dishonorably discharged]] from the Army.<ref name="trutv.com">{{cite web | last =Bell | first =Rachael | title =Paul Durousseau, the Jacksonville Serial Killer | work =Crime Library | publisher =truTV | date = | url =http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/paul_durousseau/index.html | accessdate =6 April 2013 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20130326025529/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/paul_durousseau/index.html | archive-date =26 March 2013 | url-status =dead }}</ref>{{rp|3}}
Durousseau and his wife moved to [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]], [[Florida]], where they had two daughters. It was during that period that he committed most of the murders. He struggled to keep jobs to make ends meet, and the couple would often have fights over the issue of finances. In 1999, the police advised Durousseau's wife on how to file for a [[restraining order]] after he allegedly slapped her in the face and grabbed her by the neck. Later, she testified he got violently angry when she talked about getting a [[divorce]]. In September and October 2001, Durousseau spent 48 days in jail for [[Domestic violence|domestic battery]].<ref name="trutv.com"/>
Durousseau still managed to hold various legitimate jobs. In 2001, he was hired as a school bus driver and an animal control worker despite being a convicted felon. In 2003, he worked as a [[Taxicab|taxi]] driver and it is now accepted that this is how he first came into contact with some of his victims. It was erroneously reported that Gator City Taxi Company failed to run a background check on Durousseau;<ref>{{cite news| url=http://jacksonville.bizjournals.com/jacksonville/stories/2003/07/21/story4.html | first=Paul | last=Ivice | publisher=Jacksonville Business Journal |title=Gator City Taxi sued in 3 deaths | date=July 21, 2003}}</ref> the City of Jacksonville was responsible for the background check, and issued Durousseau's taxi driver permit.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.coj.net/departments/parking-facilities-and-enforcement/motor-vehicle-inspections.aspx |title=Vehicle For Hire and Driver Certifications |website=coj.net |publisher= |accessdate=October 10, 2014}}</ref>
Neighbors and friends described Durousseau as a "lewd womanizer". He often asked young women when they planned to "make flicks" with him. A witness recalled Durousseau hitting on a girl that appeared to be around 13 or 14 years old.<ref>{{cite web | last = Treen | first = Dana | title = Accused killer was lewd, say neighbors | work = jacksonville.com | publisher = The Florida Times-Union | date = 19 June 2003 | url =http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/061903/met_12829524.shtml | accessdate = }}</ref>
== Chronology of the murders == Less than one month after the [[acquittal]] over the rape charges, the nude body of 26-year-old Tracy Habersham was found on September 7, 1997 in [[Fort Benning]].<ref name="news4jax.com">{{cite web | title = Suspected Serial Killer Under Arrest | work = News4Jax.com | publisher = WJXT | date = 18 June 2003 | url = http://www.news4jax.com/news/2275524/detail.html | url-status = dead | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100714151920/http://www.news4jax.com/news/2275524/detail.html | archivedate = 14 July 2010 }}</ref> She had been missing for 48 hours and was last seen leaving a party. She had been [[rape]]d and [[strangulation|strangled]] to death with a cord. Durousseau was not a suspect in the murder, but [[DNA profiling|DNA]] would later tie him to the crime. He later confessed to Habersham's killing after his arrest.<ref name="jacksonville.com"/><ref>{{cite web | title = Serial murder suspect linked to 1997 murder in Columbus, Ga. | work = First Coast News | publisher = Gannett Broadcasting | date = 19 June 2003 | url = http://www.firstcoastnews.com/news/news-article.aspx?storyid=5133 | accessdate = }}{{Dead link|date=May 2020 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In 1999, Durousseau raped and killed 24-year-old Tyresa Mack in her apartment. Witnesses saw him leave her place carrying a television.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pysih.com/paul-durousseau/ |title=Paul Durousseau |date=June 11, 2007 |website=pysih.com |publisher= |accessdate=October 10, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170812103900/http://pysih.com/paul-durousseau/ |archive-date=August 12, 2017 |url-status=dead }}{{Verify credibility|date=April 2013}}</ref> In 2001, he was arrested for raping a young woman in Jacksonville. He spent 30 days in jail and received two years' [[probation]]. On December 19, 2002, 18-year-old Nicole L. Williams' body was found wrapped in a blue blanket at the bottom of a ditch in Jacksonville. She had been reported missing two days earlier.<ref name="news4jax.com"/>
On January 1, 2003, family members of 19-year-old Nikia Kilpatrick went to check on her. They had not had any news from her for several days. They found her body in the bedroom of her apartment. She had been raped then killed by strangulation with a cord two days before. Her two sons, an eleven-month-old and a two-year-old, were alive but [[Malnutrition|malnourished]]. Kilpatrick was approximately six months pregnant at the time of her death.<ref name="trutv.com" /> Eight days later, 20-year-old [[Certified Nurse Assistant|nurse assistant]] Shawanda Denise McCalister, who was also pregnant at the time of her death, was raped and strangled in her Jacksonville apartment. The murder scene was almost identical to that of Kilpatrick. She was killed on Durousseau's first day of driving a cab for Gator City Taxi. Her body was found the following day.
The next two victims were 17-year-old Jovanna Jefferson, and 19-year-old Surita Cohen. Their bodies were found close to each other in a ditch next to a construction site on New Kings Road in Jacksonville on February 5. Police estimated that Jefferson was murdered around January 20 and Cohen was killed 10 days later. Witnesses recount having seen the two last victims with a taxi driver fitting Paul Durousseau's description on the night they disappeared.
Durousseau was arrested and charged with five counts of murder on June 17, 2003. On December 13, 2007 he was [[death penalty|sentenced to death]] by [[lethal injection]] for the murder of Tyresa Mack. As of August 18, 2013, he was still a resident on Florida's death row at [[Union Correctional Institution]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Inmate Population Information Detail|url=http://www.dc.state.fl.us/activeinmates/detail.asp?Bookmark=1&From=list&SessionID=534230036|work=5/26/2013|publisher=Florida Department of Corrections|accessdate=28 May 2013}}</ref> In January 2017, Durousseau's death sentence was overturned by the [[Florida Supreme Court]]. The jury that sentenced Dorousseau was split 10-2 and the high court declared a split decision unconstitutional in capital sentencing <ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.news4jax.com/news/florida-supreme-court-tosses-taxi-driver-killers-death-sentence |title = Florida Supreme Court tosses Jacksonville killer's death sentence|date = February 2017}}</ref>
